com.github.alexjlockwood.kyrie

Class Animation<T,V>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.github.alexjlockwood.kyrie.Animation<T,V>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The animation's original value type.
    V - The animation's transformed value type.

    public final class Animation<T,V>
extends Object
    An Animation encapsulates the information required to animate a single property of a Node.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static interface  Animation.BidirectionalValueTransformer<T,V>
      Interface that can transform type T to another type V and back again.
      static interface  Animation.RepeatMode
      Repeat mode determines how a repeating animation should behave once it completes.
      static interface  Animation.ValueTransformer<T,V>
      Interface that can transform type T to another type V.

      This value used used with the repeatCount(int) property to repeat the animation indefinitely.

    • Field Detail

      • INFINITE

        public static final int INFINITE
        This value used used with the repeatCount(int) property to repeat the animation indefinitely. Also used to indicate infinite duration.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • ofFloat

        @NonNull
public static Animation<Float,Float> ofFloat(Float... values)
        Constructs and returns an Animation that animates between float values. A single value implies that the value is the one being animated to, in which case the start value will be derived from the property being animated and the target object when the animation is started. Two values imply starting and ending values. More than two values imply a starting value, values to animate through along the way, and an ending value (these values will be distributed evenly across the duration of the animation).
        Parameters:
        values - A set of values that the animation will animate through over time.
        Returns:
        A new Animation.

      • ofFloat

        @NonNull
 @SafeVarargs
public static Animation<Float,Float> ofFloat(Keyframe<Float>... values)
        Same as ofFloat(Float...) except with Keyframes instead of float values.
        Parameters:
        values - A set of Keyframes that the animation will animate through over time.
        Returns:
        A new Animation.

      • ofArgb

        @NonNull
public static Animation<Integer,Integer> ofArgb(Integer... values)
        Constructs and returns an Animation that animates between color values. A single value implies that the value is the one being animated to, in which case the start value will be derived from the property being animated and the target object when the animation is started. Two values imply starting and ending values. More than two values imply a starting value, values to animate through along the way, and an ending value (these values will be distributed evenly across the duration of the animation).
        Parameters:
        values - A set of values that the animation will animate through over time.
        Returns:
        A new Animation.

      • ofArgb

        @NonNull
 @SafeVarargs
public static Animation<Integer,Integer> ofArgb(Keyframe<Integer>... values)
        Same as ofArgb(Integer...) except with Keyframes instead of color values.
        Parameters:
        values - A set of Keyframes that the animation will animate through over time.
        Returns:
        A new Animation.

      • ofFloatArray

        @NonNull
public static Animation<float[],float[]> ofFloatArray(float[]... values)
        Constructs and returns an Animation that animates between float[] values. A single value implies that the value is the one being animated to, in which case the start value will be derived from the property being animated and the target object when the animation is started. Two values imply starting and ending values. More than two values imply a starting value, values to animate through along the way, and an ending value (these values will be distributed evenly across the duration of the animation).
        Parameters:
        values - A set of values that the animation will animate through over time. The float[] values should all have the same length.
        Returns:
        A new Animation.

      • ofFloatArray

        @NonNull
 @SafeVarargs
public static Animation<float[],float[]> ofFloatArray(Keyframe<float[]>... values)
        Same as #ofFloatArray(float[]...) except with Keyframes instead of float[] values.
        Parameters:
        values - A set of Keyframes that the animation will animate through over time.
        Returns:
        A new Animation.

      • ofPathMorph

        @NonNull
public static Animation<PathData,PathData> ofPathMorph(PathData... values)
        Constructs and returns an Animation that animates between PathData values. A single value implies that the value is the one being animated to, in which case the start value will be derived from the property being animated and the target object when the animation is started. Two values imply starting and ending values. More than two values imply a starting value, values to animate through along the way, and an ending value (these values will be distributed evenly across the duration of the animation).
        Parameters:
        values - A set of values that the animation will animate through over time. The PathData values should all be morphable with each other.
        Returns:
        A new Animation.

      • ofPathMorph

        @NonNull
 @SafeVarargs
public static Animation<PathData,PathData> ofPathMorph(Keyframe<PathData>... values)
        Same as ofPathMorph(PathData...) except with Keyframes instead of float[] values.
        Parameters:
        values - A set of Keyframes that the animation will animate through over time.
        Returns:
        A new Animation.

      • ofPathMotion

        @NonNull
public static Animation<PointF,PointF> ofPathMotion(Path path)
        Constructs and returns an Animation that animates through PointF values in order to simulate motion along the given path. Clients can use transform(ValueTransformer) to transform the returned animation into one that outputs floats corresponding to the path's x/y coordinates.
        Parameters:
        path - The path to animate values along.
        Returns:
        A new Animation.

      • getStartDelay

        public long getStartDelay()
        Gets the start delay of the animation.
        Returns:
        The start delay of the animation in milliseconds.

      • startDelay

        @NonNull
public Animation<T,V> startDelay(long startDelay)
        Sets the start delay of the animation.
        Parameters:
        startDelay - The start delay of the animation in milliseconds.
        Returns:
        This Animation object (to allow for chaining of calls to setter methods).

      • getDuration

        public long getDuration()
        Gets the duration of the animation.
        Returns:
        The length of the animation in milliseconds.

      • duration

        @NonNull
public Animation<T,V> duration(long duration)
        Sets the duration of the animation.
        Parameters:
        duration - The length of the animation in milliseconds.
        Returns:
        This Animation object (to allow for chaining of calls to setter methods).

      • getRepeatCount

        public int getRepeatCount()
        Defines how many times the animation should repeat. The default value is 0.
        Returns:
        The number of times the animation should repeat, or INFINITE.

      • repeatCount

        @NonNull
public Animation<T,V> repeatCount(int repeatCount)
        Sets how many times the animation should be repeated. If the repeat count is 0, the animation is never repeated. If the repeat count is greater than 0 or INFINITE, the repeat mode will be taken into account. The repeat count is 0 by default.
        Parameters:
        repeatCount - The number of times the animation should be repeated.
        Returns:
        This Animation object (to allow for chaining of calls to setter methods).

      • getRepeatMode

        public int getRepeatMode()
        Defines what this animation should do when it reaches the end.
        Returns:
        Either one of Animation.RepeatMode.RESTART or Animation.RepeatMode.REVERSE.

      • repeatMode

        @NonNull
public Animation<T,V> repeatMode(int repeatMode)
        Defines what this animation should do when it reaches the end. This setting is applied only when the repeat count is either greater than 0 or INFINITE. Defaults to Animation.RepeatMode.RESTART.
        Parameters:
        repeatMode - Animation.RepeatMode.RESTART or Animation.RepeatMode.REVERSE.
        Returns:
        This Animation object (to allow for chaining of calls to setter methods).

      • getInterpolator

        @Nullable
public TimeInterpolator getInterpolator()
        Returns the timing interpolator that this animation uses. If null, a LinearInterpolator will be used by default.
        Returns:
        The timing interpolator for this animation.

      • interpolator

        @NonNull
public Animation<T,V> interpolator(@Nullable
                                            TimeInterpolator interpolator)
        Sets the timing interpolator that this animation uses. If null, a LinearInterpolator will be used by default.
        Parameters:
        interpolator - The timing interpolator that this animation uses.
        Returns:
        This Animation object (to allow for chaining of calls to setter methods).

      • getTotalDuration

        public long getTotalDuration()
        Gets the total duration of the animation in milliseconds, accounting for start delay and repeat count. Returns INFINITE if the repeat count is infinite.
        Returns:
        Total time an animation takes to finish, starting from the time it is started. INFINITE will be returned if the animation repeats infinite times.

      • getAnimatedValue

        @NonNull
public V getAnimatedValue(float fraction)
        Returns the animated value of this animation at the given fraction.
        Parameters:
        fraction - The current animation fraction. Typically between 0 and 1 (but may slightly extend these bounds depending on the interpolator used).
        Returns:
        The animated value of this animation at the given fraction.

      • transform

        @NonNull
public <W> Animation<T,W> transform(Animation.ValueTransformer<T,W> transformer)
        Creates a new animation with original value type T and a new transformed value type W.
        Type Parameters:
        W - The animation's new transformed value type.
        Parameters:
        transformer - The value transformer to use to transform the animation's original type T to a new transformed value type W.
        Returns:
        A new animation with the same original value type T and transformed value type W.
